citation.article-title: Vibrio azureus sp. nov., a luminous marine bacterium isolated from seawater
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Vibrio azureus sp. nov.
Vibrio azureus (a.zur′e.us. N.L. masc. adj. azureus azure blue, referring to the colour of emitted light).
Gram-negative, oxidase-positive, catalase-positive and motile by means of more than one polar flagellum.
Non-pigmented, translucent, luminescent colonies with weak swarming are formed on marine agar.
Round, 5–7 mm green colonies are formed on TCBS agar.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0.5, 2.0, 3.5 and 6.0 % NaCl (w/v), but not at 8.0 or 10.0 % NaCl; growth occurs at 10–37 °C, but not at 4 °C.
Positive for indole production and fermentation of glucose and amygdalin.
Positive enzyme activities are seen for protease, alkaline phosphatase, esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase.

Major fatty acids are C15 : 0 iso 2-OH and/or C16 : 1ω7c, C18 : 1ω7c, C16 : 0, C14 : 0, C12 : 0, C17 : 1ω8c, C16 : 1 iso I and/or C14 : 0 3-OH, C15 : 0, C18 : 0, C17 : 0, C16 : 0ω7c alcohol and C12 : 0 3-OH.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 45.2 mol%.
The type strain is LC2-005T (=NBRC 104587T =KCTC 22352T), isolated from seawater of Kuroshio Region, Japan.
